Award.AwardTitle: Heterogeneous Catalysis on Plasmonic Metallic Nanostructures: Selective Catalytic Conversion at Lower Temperatures co-Driven by Solar and Thermal Energy
Award.AbstractNarration:
Professor Suljo Linic of the University of Michigan Ann Arbor is jointly supported by the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Division of Chemistry and the Catalysis and Biocatalysis Program of the Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems Division to test the hypothesis that plasmonic nanostructures of silver (Ag) can concurrently utilize thermal energy and a low intensity photon flux to drive catalytic oxidation reactions on Ag nanoparticles at lower temperatures than conventional thermally-driven processes. Ag nanostructures of targeted sizes and shapes will be prepared and used to tune the energy of surface plasmons and control the transfer of energetic electrons into adsorbate states (orbitals) in order to achieve selective chemical transformations. The proposed experiments will be combined with theoretical calculations.

Despite substantial advances in the science of heterogeneous catalysis over the years, much remains to be done for the rational design and synthesis of catalytic materials for targeted chemical transformations. The proposed research will focus on the investigation of the potential of plasmonic metallic nanostructures to activate targeted chemical transformations using low intensity light flux, allowing the catalysts to operate at lower temperatures. This promises to significantly improve catalysts stability, energy efficiency, and product selectivity. Students will be trained in sophisticated research methods, and activities will be organized to educate high school students and the general public on heterogeneous catalysis using web vehicles of content delivery such as YouTube.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Metal nanoparticles are used as commercial catalysts for many chemical transformations, including ammonia synthesis, hydrocarbon reforming, oxidation, and hydrogenation reactions. All these reactions are triggered by thermal heating of nanoparticles, which couples the phonon models of the nanoparticles with adsorbates. This coupling results in the evolution of the adsorbate from the reactant to the product state on the ground state potential energy surface. As such, these reactions usually require relatively high temperatures, and the product selectivity is governed and limited by the ground state free energy landscape.

Chemical reactions on metal surfaces can also be activated in an alternative mechanism with energetic electrons. In this mechanism, energetic electrons scatter through unpopulated states (orbitals) of adsorbates, transiently populating these orbitals, and in this process inducing forces on atoms in adsorbates. These forces lead to the movement of the atoms, which can result in the activation of chemical bonds and chemical transformations. This electron-mediated mechanism of bond activation was elucidated in a number of experiments in the 1980 and 1990’s. This electron-mediated mechanism of activating surface chemical reactions on metals offers opportunities to: (i) move away from the reaction selectivities governed (and limited) by the ground state potential energy surfaces, and (ii) in principle allows for lower operating temperature where chemical reactions are triggered by an electron excitation as opposed to thermally induced excitation of phonon modes of the substrate.  Lower operating temperatures could lead to an improved stability of the materials and processes.

While the opportunities presented by the electron-driven photo-chemistry on metals are appealing, the required use of high intensity light to achieve meaningful reaction rates had made this process of bond activation irrelevant from the practical application perspective. The high intensity of light was required since the fraction of photons that are converted into energetic electrons that reach the surface of the metal single crystal is fairly low, i.e., most energetic electrons are formed in the bulk, far away from the surface, and do not reach the surface before their energy is dissipated through the collisions with other electrons and atoms.We demonstrated that unlike metal single crystals, plasmonic metal nanoparticles can activate electron-driven chemical reactions at meaningful rates even when illuminated with low intensity light, the order of Solar intensity. Our main findings are:

  1. We observed that when plamonic nanoparticles (ie, silver) are illuminated with low intensity resonant light (ie, the light that excites localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR), the rate of catalytic oxidation reaction on these nanoparticles at a given temperature is enhanced, i.e., a photo-catalytic reaction channel is activated. We note that we had established that these oxidation reactions on silver were limited by the rate of the O2 dissociation. These observations were published in Nature Chemistry (3, 467, 2011).
  2. We proposed that these photo-catalytic reactions proceed by LSPR-mediated transient transfer of energetic electrons to antibonding adsorbate (O2) states. This process induces forces on atoms in the molecule, causing it to gain vibrational energy and eventually react. In the case of the dissociation of O2 adsorbed on silver, an electron transiently populates the O2 antibonding orbital. This induces a force along the O-O bond, which results in the activation of the bond. The mechanism was discussed in publicationsin Nature Chemistry (3, 467, 2011) and Nature Materials (11, 1044, 2012)
